awd_titl_txt: FMSG: Rapidly Repurposing and Scaling Assembly Lines Through the Co-design of Tooling and Controls of Robotic Work Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
This project allows re-purposing and re-scaling of manufacturing production lines to be done quickly and affordably. A typical manufacturing assembly line is composed of a sequence of work cells, each requiring different mechanisms to execute different processes. Automated production in this framework is often inflexible – a change in the production requires the time-consuming re-design and expensive reprogramming of components. As a result, an automated assembly line production is unable to respond to rapid changes in market needs. This not only limits the speed of product updates and response to market dynamics, but also impedes manufacturers from reacting quickly during a national emergency when that flexibility is essential for a national response. This project changes how assembly lines can be rapidly updated on the factory floor, focusing on two specific but widely-used automated tasks, making assembly lines more intelligent and responsive to the production of changing products lines, and contributing to the goal of "manufacturing as a service."

This project develops an efficient approach to co-design of task-specific tooling and control, applicable in general for manufacturing systems, uniting digital fabrication with digital assembly. The project focuses two assembly tasks, re-orientation and insertion, with their co-design of tooling and controls as cyber-physical sub-systems.  The project draws upon the disciplines and technologies for robotics, controller optimization, algorithmic design, software and hardware, material science, mechanical engineering, and manufacturing science and engineering.  The project takes a model-based data-driven approach to object manipulation, developing families of algorithms for co-design of tooling and controls, using techniques from artificial intelligence and machine learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SOC STUDIES OF SCI, ENG & TECH
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The objective of our project was to explore innovative methods for creating robotic systems adaptable for use in manufacturing assembly lines. Traditional assembly line robots perform repetitive tasks, and using highly versatile, articulated robotic end effectors is often not cost-effective. However, simpler robotic systems lack the flexibility to quickly adapt to changing market demands and product innovations, a limitation highlighted during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Our research introduces novel algorithms and systems to solve this challenge. We have developed a unique system for automatically creating non-actuated robotic grippers. These grippers, when attached to a robotic arm, can handle a wide range of objects. Importantly, our grippers are 3D printable and cost-effective, with a production cost of approximately $20 using low-cost Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) systems. Assuming a 5-year amortization for the active gripper, our system remains more cost-effective as long as a manufacturing line necessitates changes no more frequently than every week, a rate significantly below the industry average.

For more intricate tasks like insertion, we have designed advanced compliant systems. These include: 1) Innovative materials with programmable compliance to suit various needs; 2) New types of metamaterials capable of exerting forces safely; and 3) A novel architecture for compliant robotic grippers, using a fractal design. This design allows the grippers to be both flexible and capable of becoming rigid, enabling vacuum adhesion to adjust to different part shapes.

The broader impact of this project extends beyond providing novel solutions for assembly lines, which have already garnered interest from multiple companies. Significantly, the project has supported the intellectual development of multiple PhD students, undergraduates, and junior faculty members. The findings and technological advancements of our work have been integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses, offering stimulating and practical examples that enrich the educational experience.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2023
Modified by: Adriana Schulz
